etymology.description: 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") + 辣(辣) (là, "spicy") as phonetic = sound association with mouth -> trumpet sound
etymology.interpretation: The character 喇(lǎ, "horn") combines the mouth radical 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") with a phonetic component 辣(辣) (là), indicating sound production related to wind instruments like trumpets.

examples.chinese: 号角发出清脆的喇响(號角發出清脆的喇響)。
examples.pinyin: Hàojiǎo fāchū qīngcuì de lǎ xiǎng.
examples.english: The trumpet produced a clear, ringing sound.

examples.chinese: 战鼓隆隆作响时(戰鼓隆隆作響時)，喇声随风传来(喇聲隨風傳來)。
examples.pinyin: Zhàngǔ lónglóng zuòxiǎng shí, lǎ shēng suí fēng chuán lái.
examples.english: When the battle drums roared, the sound of the horn spread with the wind.

examples.chinese: 古代仪式上(古代儀式上)，喇声悠扬回荡(喇聲悠揚迴蕩)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔdài yíshì shàng, lǎ shēng yōuyáng huídàng.
examples.english: During ancient ceremonies, the sound of the horn resonated gracefully.
